Art. 4.54. 
Administration and liquidation by an administrator 
The beneficiary heir may discharge himself of the administration and liquidation of the succession. He must first have an administrator appointed by order of the family court, upon request, to whom he will hand over all the property of the succession, on condition that the administrator liquidates it in accordance with the rules prescribed below.
 In the event that the interests of hereditary creditors or legatees could be compromised by the negligence or financial situation of the beneficiary heir, any interested party may cause him to be replaced by an administrator responsible for liquidating the succession.
This administrator is appointed by an order made in summary proceedings, the heir being heard or called beforehand.
 The order appointing an administrator pursuant to paragraphs 1 and 2 is entered in the central register of successions within fifteen days.
 The administrator appointed in accordance with paragraphs 1 and 2 has the same powers as the beneficiary heir himself.
 He is subject to the same obligations as the heir. He is exempt from providing security.
